Among right-handed surgeons is not infrecuet to inclict accidentally themselves with suture needles or other cutting objects to the left hand.  If the patient's wound is infected you have quite a deal to become infected.  In those times when there were no antibiotics the most common infection was produced by streptococci beta hemoliticus which may produce erisipelas which jeopardize,the viability of the limb and become complicated with septisemia.  That explains why the articles mention that Dr. Willson was very ill, in danger of loosing the arm or geting a blood poison.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: Dr. Duarte: Thanks for the additional information on the likely cause of Dr. Wilson's illness.  It's a little hard for us to be certain whether or not the image is a mirror view.  I checked with my colleague who works a lot with the negatives and the digital images -- he often uses the way the coats or vests button as a clue as to whether the image has been reversed.   He notes that the vest buttoning would suggest the image is not reversed.  The captioning on the original print and Bain's added caption imply this is correct reading, too.   But you can tell by the tack in the upper left corner of the image that this is a copy of an existing photographic print, and that print could, conceivably, have been reversed.  Alternatively, the article may also have reported it incorrectly, as the left hand could have been injured in the way that you suggest, assuming Dr. Wilson was right-handed.
